question_stem: The graph of \(y = g(x)\) is shown below. It intersects the x-axis at \(x = -1\) and \(x = 3\), and has a minimum point at \((1, -2)\).

parts.question_text: State the coordinates of the x-intercepts and the minimum point of the graph \(y = 3g(x)\).
parts.solution_text:
The graph of \(y = 3g(x)\) is a vertical stretch of the graph \(y = g(x)\) by a factor of 3.  The x-intercepts remain unchanged, as stretching vertically does not affect where the graph crosses the x-axis. Therefore, the x-intercepts are still \(x = -1\) and \(x = 3\), which correspond to the coordinates \((-1, 0)\) and \((3, 0)\). 

The minimum point of \(y = g(x)\) is at \((1, -2)\).  When the graph is stretched vertically by a factor of 3, the y-coordinate of the minimum point is multiplied by 3. Thus, the new minimum point is at \((1, 3 \times -2)\), which simplifies to \((1, -6)\).
